framework_intro.para: Below is a suggested framework to help you structure this type of report. There are spaces for you to add your notes and the content of your report.
You can visit the help section to learn more about Oxford iWriter.

commentary.para: A report describes a study, an investigation or a project. Its purpose is to provide recommendations or updates, and sometimes to persuade readers to accept an idea. It is written by a single person or a group who has investigated the issue. It is read by people who require the information.
Below is a framework for creating long reports.
The model you will see is an executive summary of a longer report so it does not include all of these sections.
In order to plan the report, the writer decides what to cover in each paragraph and takes notes.
The writer uses key words or phrases to:

checklist.point: Do your research and gather all your information, including facts and figures.
Organize your notes into the framework.
Ask yourself questions about your readers.
Use language to state your objectives.
Use language to outline your research and present your findings.
Use language to give conclusions and recommendations.
Make your report as long as necessary but as short as possible.
The main body of your report should be mainly factual and not based on opinion.
Do I have all the sections I need?
Does the title clearly show what the report is about?
Does the contents list have the same headings and numbers as the report?
Is the summary an accurate statement of the report?
Does the introduction state the purpose of the report?
Does the introduction say what the report will (and won't) cover?
Does the introduction explain the research?
Does the body of the report use headings and numbers?
Would tables or diagrams to make the information clearer?
Does the conclusion clearly give my opinion about the findings?
Are my recommendations really based on my conclusion?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar and spelling?

paragraph.name: Title
paragraph.desc: Your title should tell the reader exactly what the report is about.

paragraph.name: Contents list
paragraph.desc: If your report has a number of sections, it is important to include a table of contents so that the readers can find the information they want. Use the same section headings or numbers as you do in the main part of the report.

content.para: (Contents list optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)

paragraph.name: Summary
paragraph.desc: Include a summary of the purpose and objectives of the report, the kind of research you did, the main findings and conclusions, and your recommendations, if any.
paragraph.tip: TIP This is often called an executive summary. It follows the structure of the main report.

content.para: (Summary optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)

paragraph.name: Introduction
paragraph.desc: Give the background to why you are writing the report and explains what the report covers and what research you did.

notes.para: Compare 2 web designs—see which people prefer.
What attracts people and makes them buy products?

content.para: The purpose of this report is to compare two different web designs. The reason for this is to decide what kind of web page is most likely to attract new customers and to encourage existing customers to buy more products from us.

paragraph.name: Main body of report
paragraph.desc: Give precise information about your research and what you have found.
paragraph.tip: TIP You can include tables and diagrams here, or these can be in an appendix.

notes.para: Asked 2 developers for different page designs—one simple (A), one more sophisticated (B).
Research: 2 groups of 20 people (range of ages, professions, computer knowledge).
Made 2 groups: one used A, one B, once a dayfor a month to do tasks: buying, getting info, returning goods, tracking.
Also asked about technology for accessing Internet.

content.para: We asked two developers to produce alternative web pages for our company. We asked Developer A to produce a simple, easy-to-use design and we asked Developer B to produce a more sophisticated design with lots of eye-catching graphics. We conducted our research by asking a group of twenty existing customers and twenty non-customers to use the web page over a month. The group was made up of people with a range of ages, professions, incomes, and computer expertise. We divided the group in two and asked one sub-group to use Design A and the other to use Design B. We asked each sub-group to log on once a day and to use the web page to perform certain tasks, including: buying products, getting information, returning damaged products, and tracking deliveries. We also asked the sub-groups to assess how attractive they found their designs and whether they would be encouraged to return to the web page.
In addition, we researched the technology that people had available for accessing the Internet, including the devices people used and the connection speeds available.

paragraph.name: Conclusions/Findings
paragraph.desc: Give the facts you have discovered and your opinions on them.

notes.para: People liked easy-to-use page (A) for buying.
Don't want entertainment—Design B may be slow to load, etc.

content.para: We found that, on the whole, people preferred to be able to purchase products quickly and easily. In conclusion, users do not visit a site such as ours for entertainment, and while they initially enjoyed some of the aspects of Design B these could take a long time to load and users eventually became bored.

paragraph.name: Recommendations
paragraph.tip: TIP You can also predict what will happen if they are followed.

notes.para: Adopt Design A (simple) with some features of B.

content.para: We recommend that we adopt Design A with two or three of the more practical features from Design B.

paragraph.name: Appendices
paragraph.desc: Give more detailed information here, with cross references to the appendices in the body of the report.

content.para: (Appendices optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)

paragraph.name: Bibliography
paragraph.desc: Give a list of any other publications you refer to in your report.

content.para: (Bibliography optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)
